docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Steven Lofton, Roger Croteau and Mr. Lofton's five foster children -- who were born to H.I.V.-positive mothers -- prepare Thanksgiving dinner, it will be in a kitchen in Portland, Ore., with cobalt blue walls and fire-engine-red Formica cabinets. Then they will join more than 20 guests in a dining room with an orange tabletop, yellow carpeting and a silver ceiling. ''Some of us are people of color,'' Mr. Lofton, 46, said, referring to his interracial family. ''And some of us are people who love color.''

headline.main: Married or Not, It's a Full House

docs.abstract: Article on Portland home of Steven Lofton and Roger Croteau, who are raising five foster children born to HIV-positive mothers; interview; photos; Lofton and Croteau, pediatric nurses, moved family to Oregon after Florida refused to allow adoption of one boy who tested HIV-negative, which made him eligible for adoption; Florida bars adoptions by homosexuals, although case is still in courts; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite its shortcomings, the Medicare prescription drug bill heading for a vote in Congress is worthy of passage. Fears that the legislation contains seeds that will ultimately destroy the traditional Medicare program strike us as overblown. Our own chief qualm is that the country, with deficits looming as far as prognosticators can see, cannot afford a program that will cost, at a minimum, $400 billion over 10 years. Millions of middle-income Americans will get only modest help from the program, and they will have to cope with a crazy-quilt pattern of benefits. But fortunately, the bill is strongest when it comes to the most important target groups: elderly people with low incomes or very high drug bills.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs Medicare prescription drug bill despite its shortcomings; notes bill is at its strongest in aiding elderly with low incomes or very high drug bills; calls overblown fears that bill will ultimately destroy traditional Medicare program; expresses concern about $400 billion cost of program over 10 years; urges rescinding tax cuts for wealthy to pay for drug benefit
docs.snippet: Despite its shortcomings, the Medicare prescription drug bill heading for a vote in Congress is worthy of passage. Fears that the legislation contains seeds that will ultimately destroy the traditional Medicare program strike us as overblown. Our own...

docs.lead_paragraph: Critics of the Medicare plan devised by Congressional leaders said yesterday that it contained little in the way of mechanisms to slow the runaway costs of drugs and medical services even as it provided tens of billions of dollars for hospitals, health plans, employers, doctors and the drug industry. With the full details of the proposal not yet public, some policy analysts also expressed doubt that the compromise, reached over the weekend, would stay within the 10-year, $400 billion cost that Congress allotted to a Medicare overhaul. The legislation would provide a prescription drug benefit for the first time to 40 million disabled and elderly Americans.

headline.main: Medicare Compromise Plan Won't Cut Costs, Critics Say

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and MILT FREUDENHEIM

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE might think that being released from prison is a joyous experience and that an inmate would be giddy with the anticipated freedom that lays ahead. But the reality is often more complicated than that. For Yolanda Crespo, who was released last month from the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla, thinking about the day she would walk out of the prison doors brought a mix of emotions. Certainly, she felt relief, but equally powerful, she felt fear.

headline.main: For Released Inmates, Someone to Talk To

docs.abstract: Article on new prerelease program at Westchester County Jail in Valhalla, NY, run by Westchester Jewish Community Services, which links female inmates leaving prison with volunteer mentors from community; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS, who pay the highest drug prices in the world, are clamoring for access to cheap imports of prescription drugs. The governors of Illinois, Minnesota, Iowa and Wisconsin -- Democrats and Republicans alike -- want their constituents to be able to buy drugs from Canada. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says he would like the same option for New York City employees and hospitals. Municipal workers in Springfield, Mass., already have that right, though federal regulators threaten to stop them.

headline.main: The Nation: Prescriptions Filled; If Americans Want to Pay Less for Drugs, They Will

docs.abstract: Demands by American consumers and states for lower prescription-drug prices discussed; manufacturers have spent millions to discourage Congress from legalizing imports, but some industry executives acknowledge uphill fight to keep drugs as only legal products specifically banned from being imported; photo; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A YEAR-END financial review is always advisable if you want to reduce your tax bill next April, but it is especially crucial this year as the effects of three years' worth of tax legislation come into play. ''The tax act of 2003 and provisions of prior laws are all coming together,'' said Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and accountant.

headline.main: Personal Business; How Tax Changes Can Help You (Hint: Plan Now)

docs.abstract: Advice on opportunities and pitfalls facing taxpayers this year as result of tax law changes; photo (M)
